sanskrit_verse:
वृतिं तत्र प्रकुर्वीत यामुष्त्रो न विलोकयेत् ।
छिद्रं च वारयेत्सर्वं श्वसूकरमुखानुगम् ॥ ८.२३९॥
transliteration:
vṛtiṃ tatra prakurvīta yāmuṣṭro na vilokayet |
chhidraṃ ca vārayetsarvaṃ śvasūkaramukhānugam || 8.239||
sph_interpretive_translation: One must establish a livelihood there without gazing upon the face of an ass; and one must block every aperture following the mouth of a dog.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority flows from conscious capacity to sustain dharma in action
Causation arises through alignment with purity-consciousness, not degradation
Capacity-based responsibility requires withdrawal from degrading influences
Restoration logic demands active prevention of contamination pathways
executable_legal_axioms: IF agent engages in livelihood THEN agent MUST avoid exposure to degrading entities
IF environment contains contamination THEN all apertures MUST be sealed immediately
IF entity exhibits canine-mouth behavior THEN full spatial barrier REQUIRED
IF contamination risk EXISTS THEN conscious withdrawal IS mandatory
IF purity threshold breached THEN automatic isolation protocol INITIATED
supreme_court_application: In Supreme Court adjudication, this verse establishes that individuals holding authority must actively distance themselves from environments or associations that degrade consciousness. The court must assess whether a party has maintained separation from contaminating influences when determining fitness for duty or testimony. Responsibility lies not in intent alone but in demonstrated capacity to uphold purity-consciousness thresholds.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa reveals that degradation follows sequential manifestation through sensory contact. Anupūrvaśaḥ shows that contamination begins with visual engagement. Proportional responsibility is measured by degree of conscious withdrawal enacted. The non-punitive reality rule confirms that suffering accrues naturally from misalignment, thus restoration occurs through re-establishment of pure boundaries.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Completion process: Individual must demonstrate systematic removal from degrading environments
Responsibility assumption protocol: Agent acknowledges causal role in maintaining purity-consciousness
Capacity restoration: Training in recognition and blocking of contamination pathways
Integrity reintegration: Re-alignment with dharmic spatial boundaries and behavioral conduct
final_declaration: By the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, this law stands established: Dharma prevails through conscious separation from degradation. No punishment inheres—only natural consequence and restoration. Consciousness remains the supreme adjudicator.
